fields.headline: Just say no
fields.bodyText: I was intrigued to read Boris Johnson's call for legislation to invalidate the results of ballots where less than half the eligible electorate exercise their right to participate (Second tube strike over job cuts hits millions of London commuters, 5 October). Presumably we can expect the resignation of the mayor of London (elected on a turnout of 45.33%) forthwith? Dr Richard Hayton University of Huddersfield • Dr Paul O'Kane suggests (Letters, 4 October) that the coalition should be seen in nautical terms as a catamaran. However, this implies twin hulls of roughly the same size. A better analogy would be an outrigger canoe, in which a lateral support float attached to the port (left) side gives stability to a craft which would otherwise be liable to capsize. Henry Brownrigg London • Mention of cowboy time (Letters, 20 September) reminded me of the "almost unique" configuration of time and date that will occur at 10 seconds past 10 minutes past 10am on the 10th of October this year: 10:10:10 on 10.10.10. Elizabeth Bailey Edinburgh • Years ago in Beirut, the Foreign Office official sitting next to me at a posh dinner advised me that there was only one way to get a chandelier really clean: with gin (Shortcuts, G2, 29 September). Margaret Chesworth Bath • Alain de Botton (Unwed Ed, 2 October) posits: "The real question is whether the world is yet ready for a bachelor prime minister." The world may be a different proposition, but can he have forgotten Edward Heath, prime minister 1970-74? Susan Pringle Dundee • To refer to a man as "a bachelor", when he is clearly attached and has a child, is to show that vocabulary hasn't kept pace with the reality of the 21st-century family. SFR Roome York • The late Ivor Cutler wore a button on his woolly hat that simply read "NO". Cutler called it his all-purpose protest badge (Letters, 5 October). Geoff Noble Twickenham, Middlesex
